channel.title: Recent & Upcoming Talks on Jean Monlong
channel.description: Recent content in Recent & Upcoming Talks on Jean Monlong

item.title: Genotyping structural variants in human cohorts using pangenome graphs
Genotyping structural variants in TOPMed using pangenome graphs
Genotyping structural variants in pangenome graphs using the vg toolkit
item.description: @JMonlong is presenting genotyping of structural variances in graph genomes using vg. #gi2019 Preprint: https://t.co/7R7JJ0CrCu Code: https://t.co/e6nRfAbGSj pic.twitter.com/te1eVRSysg — Martin Steinegger üá∫üá¶ (@thesteinegger) November 7, 2019 @JMonlong has some beef with the VCF format (lol don't we all!): multiple equivalent representation, over-simplification, impractical; he suggests representations based on mapping directly to the assembly #gi2019 — Daniel Standage (@byuhobbes) November 7, 2019 Nice talk from @JMonlong about SV genotyping using VG @BenedictPaten at #gi2019 .

item.title: Genome variation graphs with the vg toolkit
item.description: #ASHG19 Jean Monlong presenting overview of genome graph rep package vg GRC session pic.twitter.com/TkBWc8lI9v — Chris Boles (@tchrisboles) October 15, 2019 #ASHG19 JM: vg handling large sets of genomes pic.twitter.com/Xo01Dlf6pZ — Chris Boles (@tchrisboles) October 15, 2019 #ASHG19 JM: vg graph viewer pic.twitter.com/EexFptZWnZ — Chris Boles (@tchrisboles) October 15, 2019

item.title: Genotyping structural variants in pangenome graphs using the vg toolkit
item.description: Jean Monlong from @UCSC : Genotyping Structural Variants in Pangenome Graphs Using the VG Toolkit #nccb2019 pic.twitter.com/hjHEzJr6Cj — NCCB Symposium (@NorCalCompBio) October 12, 2019

item.title: Genome-wide characterization of copy number variants in epilepsy patients
Genome-wide characterization of copy number variants in epilepsy patients
item.description: @JMonlong talks about genome-wide characterization of copy number variants in epilepsy patients #genetics17 — Mehran Karimzadeh (@MKarimzade) April 24, 2017 Now: @JMonlong: Genome-wide Characterization of Copy Number Variants in Epilepsy Patients #genetics17 https://t.co/Ip7q3KFDsN — Michael Hoffman (@michaelhoffman) April 24, 2017 JM validates PopSV using a twin dataset. PopSV outperforms commonly used tools in detecting copy number variation #genetics17 — Mehran Karimzadeh (@MKarimzade) April 24, 2017 JM: Rare exonic CNVs enriched and more recurrent in epilepsy patients compared to controls.

item.title: Global patterns of copy number variation in humans from a population-based analysis
Population-based Detection of Structural Variants in Normal and Aberrant Genomes
Population-based Detection of Structural Variants in Normal and Aberrant Genomes
item.description: Jean Monlong SV detection in normal and aberrant genomes #gi2014 — Karyn Meltz Murphy (@karynotype) September 23, 2014 JM PopSV: population based approach. Use a set of reference experiments to detect abnormal patterns #gi2014 — Karyn Meltz Murphy (@karynotype) September 23, 2014 Monlong: rather than throw out findings in hard-to-map genome tracts, embrace them -- at population scale -- to call elusive SVs. #gi2014 — Nathan Pearson (@GenomeNathan) September 23, 2014 Jean Monlong: importance of normalization.

item.title: Population-based detection of Structural Variants in normal and aberrant genomes.
